sub_topic: Finding the projection of one vector onto another using trigonometry
message_1: A student is pushing a block with a force of 50 N at an angle of 30 degrees above the horizontal. The weight of the block is 100 N. Find the vertical component of the force acting on the block. (Assume that the force is acting on the center of the block)
message_2:
To find the vertical component of the force acting on the block, we can use the formula:

Vertical component = Force × sin(angle)

where Force is the force applied by the student (50 N) and angle is the angle above the horizontal (30 degrees).

First, we need to convert the angle from degrees to radians:

angle (in radians) = (angle in degrees) × (π / 180)
angle (in radians) = 30 × (π / 180) = π / 6

Now, we can find the vertical component of the force:

Vertical component = 50 N × sin(π / 6)
Vertical component = 50 N × 0.5 (since sin(π / 6) = 0.5)
Vertical component = 25 N

So, the vertical component of the force acting on the block is 25 N.
